title: Rob Gronkowski Lost Weight and Changed His Life
text:
Gronk is svelte.

It’s a jarring sight to anybody who marveled at Rob Gronkowski barrel downfield as the closest thing in football to a helmet-wearing rhinoceros. He was perhaps the most dominant tight end in NFL history with the Patriots precisely because of his unusual combination of size and speed. Humans so big aren’t supposed to move so fast.

Now, suddenly, he’s no longer Gronk-sized.

Since Gronkowski called it quits five months ago, he has undergone a stunning transformation: Rob Gronkowski looks like something Rob Gronkowski used to eat for a midday snack. He has slimmed down to 245 pounds, he says, after being listed at 268 for last season’s Super Bowl. The same guy who once hosted a booze-filled party cruise is now obsessed with juice cleanses and intermittent fasting.

“I’m trying to get that crap weight out of me,” he said in an interview. “I’ve never been more ripped in my life.”

Gronkowski spent years wondering something nobody else could possibly wonder: why he wasn’t more ripped. He exercised constantly. He power lifted as much as he physically could. He prided himself on how much he could squat. But it never produced the results he wanted, and immediately after this year’s Super Bowl, he saw a sign that something needed to change.

He left the Super Bowl—the same game where he made the key catch in New England’s 13-3 win—with his thigh swollen to the size of a tree trunk. Afterward, he could barely move and that night, after celebrating, he cried in bed because the pain wouldn’t let him sleep. It kept him up at night for another three weeks. He couldn’t work out at all, and it was almost two months until he could really run again. In late March, he retired.

That was the beginning of Gronkowski’s great awakening. He didn’t want to stop working out. He just wanted to approach it differently. And that began with the food.

All of his favorites had to go. Fried foods, cheeseburgers and subs were cut out. Chicken parm, which he loved to order with extra sauce, may have been the most difficult sacrifice. That was gone too. “You can’t even talk about it,” he says, “because then you’re going to want it.”

And then he started sounding like a guy at the local farmers market. He focused on eating anything organic. He was into anything that was plant-based. Some days, juices were the only thing he consumed. He’ll eat a dessert—but not if it’s made with synthetic sugar. “I’ll eat a dessert as long as it’s organic cane sugar.”

Gronkowski has even dabbled with intermittent fasting, the diet trend in which people cycle between periods of fasting and eating by going longer periods without consuming food.

But to lose weight and stay in the type of shape he wanted, he also had to completely change something besides his eating habits: the way he exercises. This year he doesn’t have an NFL season to prepare for. He could train accordingly.

Patriots tight end Rob Gronkowski reacts during overtime of the AFC Championship in January. Photo: mark rebilas/Reuters

These days, his workouts might look more like something you’d see in a barre studio than at a training camp. He’s really into band workouts. He focuses on activities that increase his flexibility. He does a lot of core exercises to improve his stability. (If you want to train like him at home: his favorite involves standing with one foot on a Bosu ball and doing chest passes with a medicine ball.) When he lifts—which he still does—he does more reps of a lighter weight, rather than trying to max out.

Gronkowski’s metamorphosis comes at a time when another player unexpectedly left the game to take care of his body. Colts quarterback Andrew Luck retired this week at 29 years old, citing the physical and mental toll that the game took on him.

Gronkowski understands. He had nine surgeries throughout his career. While he may not have walked away from nearly as much money as Luck, there are plenty of people who believe Gronkowski still has what it takes to be a game-changing force.

Gronkowski hasn’t ruled out that possibility. He says it could be months from now, or even years. It could also be never, depending on how he feels. But there’s one thing he knows for certain.

“I would definitely be eating a lot more if I was playing football,” he said. “Big time.”

description: Former Patriots tight end Rob Gronkowski has slimmed down to 245 pounds. He’s less about booze cruises now and more into juice cleanses and intermittent fasting.
